title: The Watermill with the Great Red Roof

artist:
Jan Sanders van Hemessen
Netherlandish, active c. 1519–1556
title: Judith
shortDesc: According to the biblical story, the widow Judith saved her people from slaughter by the Assyrian army by infiltrating the tent of the enemy general, Holofernes, to seduce and then behead him. Dutch painter Jan van Hemessen's life-size interpretation reflects contemporary male ambivalence toward female agency in 16th-century Netherlands. It celebrates Judith's physical and moral strength but also foregrounds the sexuality that enabled her triumph.

title: Lady Sarah Bunbury Sacrificing to the Graces
Fishing Boats with Hucksters Bargaining for Fish
Landscape with Saint John on Patmos
American Gothic
shortDesc: One of America’s most famous paintings, American Gothic debuted at the Art Institute of Chicago, winning Grant Wood a $300 prize and instant fame. Wood used his sister and dentist as models, depicting them in front of an 1880s-style house. While the painting is often seen as a satirical commentary on the Midwestern character, Wood intended it to a positive statement about rural American values.

title: Portrait of Marevna
shortDesc: Before achieving renown as a muralist, Diego Rivera lived in Paris amid Pablo Picasso’s circle and enjoyed a brief but sparkling period as a Cubist painter. In this work he portrayed his then-lover, the Russian-born painter and writer Marevna Vorobëv-Stebelska, with her distinctive bobbed hair, blond bangs, and prominent nose. Following World War I and the Russian Revolution, Rivera rejected Cubism as frivolous and inappropriate.

title: Arrangement in Flesh Color and Brown: Portrait of Arthur Jerome Eddy

artist:
Vasily Kandinsky
Born Moscow (formerly Russian Empire, now Russia), 1866; died Neuilly-sur-Seine, France, 1944
title: Improvisation No. 30 (Cannons)
shortDesc: In his 1912 book Concerning the Spiritual in Art, Vasily Kandinsky advocated for an art that could move beyond imitation of the physical world, inspiring, as he put it, “vibrations in the soul.” Between 1910 and 1914 he produced a series of “improvisations," which he described as unconscious, spontaneous expressions. This painting—one of his first improvisations—is a standout work within the museum's modern art collection.

title: L'Estaque
shortDesc: Émilie Charmy was among the first women to exhibit paintings in the Fauvist style, marked by an expressionistic and nonnaturalistic use of color. In this boldly hued landscape, she captured the coastal town of L’Estaque, popular with French painters. The swelling shapes along the composition’s edges produce a sense of movement that dissipates at the center in the calm waters of the Bay of Marseille.

title: Champs de Mars: The Red Tower
Henry Ossawa Tanner
shortDesc: This portrait of Henry Ossawa Tanner, an internationally renowned African American painter, was made by his friend and roommate Hermann Dudley Murphy during their student days in Paris. Although both received traditional artistic training, they were drawn to the modernist techniques of James McNeill Whistler. Murphy's use of thin paint applications, a muted palette, and asymmetrical composition evoke Whistler’s style and interest in Japanese art.

title: Salome with the Head of Saint John the Baptist
Henri Degas and His Niece Lucie Degas (The Artist's Uncle and Cousin)
Woman Reading
shortDesc: Édouard Manet was a pivotal figure in the development of Impressionism and modern art. Here, an elegantly dressed Parisian woman reads a magazine, a beer close at hand—a scene that would have struck contemporary viewers as fashionable and modern. While the woman appears to be outdoors, one of Manet’s paintings serves as a backdrop and other props suggest the scene was staged in Manet’s studio.

title: Two Sisters (On the Terrace)
shortDesc: Despite the title, the young women in this painting were not actually sisters. The older girl in the center gazes absently beyond her younger companion, whose red cheeks suggest that she just dashed into the picture. These casual expressions make this “sisterly” moment feel genuine. Renoir juxtaposed the girls’ figures against a dreamy landscape, the basket of yarn evoking an artist’s palette.

title: Saint George and the Dragon
shortDesc: Bernat Martorell was one of the greatest painters in Catalonia, Spain, during the first half of the 15th century. Here, he rendered a frequently depicted episode from the popular legend of Saint George, in which the model Christian knight saves a town and rescues a beautiful princess. George’s halo and armor and the scaly dragon are richly modeled with raised stucco decoration.

title: The Night is Stirring (La nuit remue)
The Beheading of Saint John the Baptist
shortDesc: These six paintings illustrate scenes from the life of Saint John the Baptist. We see John enter the wilderness to live as a hermit, foretell Christ’s role as redeemer, be imprisoned, and finally be martyred at the request of Salomé, the step-daughter of King Herod. The artist, Giovanni di Paolo, represented figures multiple times to indicate their movement through highly imaginative and stylized settings.

title: Processional Cross with Saint Mary Magdalene and a Blessed Hermit

artist:
Rogier van der Weyden and Workshop
Netherlandish, c. 1399–1464
title: Portrait of Jean Gros (recto); Coat of Arms of Jean Gros (verso)

artist:
Jean Hey, known as The Master of Moulins
French, active c. 1475- c. 1505
title: The Annunciation

artist:
Francisco José de Goya y Lucientes
Spanish, 1746-1828
title: Friar Pedro Shoots El Maragato as His Horse Runs Off
The Bay of Marseille, Seen from L'Estaque
Beata Beatrix
shortDesc: Dante Gabriel Rossetti was a founder of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, a circle of Victorian artists united in their regard for medieval aesthetics. Inspired by his namesake, Dante, Rossetti drew parallels in this work between the Italian poet's love for Beatrice and his own affection for his deceased wife and muse, Elizabeth Siddal, a talented artist and writer who died at age 32.

title: Arrival of the Normandy Train, Gare Saint-Lazare

artist:
Arshile Gorky
American, born Ottoman Empire (Present Day Turkey) c.1904–1948
title: The Plough and the Song

artist:
Pablo Picasso (Spanish, 1881-1973)
printed by Eugène Delâtre (French, 1864-1938)
title: The Frugal Meal, from The Saltimbanques
Paris Street; Rainy Day
shortDesc: Considered Caillebotte’s masterpiece, this view of a busy intersection captures both an everyday moment and all that was new in a rapidly changing Paris. The clothes are the latest fashion. The retractable umbrella was just invented. And a decades-long renovation had transformed the medieval streets of Paris into grand boulevards, like the ones seen here. It's a painting you want to walk into.

artist:
Marc Chagall
Born Vitebsk (formerly Russian Empire, now Belarus), 1887; died Saint-Paul, France, 1985
title: The Praying Jew
year: 1923 (one of two versions after a 1914 composition)

title: Virgin and Child with the Young Saint John the Baptist

artist:
Katsushika Hokusai 葛飾 北斎 
Japanese, 1760-1849
title: Under the Wave off Kanagawa (Kanagawa oki nami ura), also known as The Great Wave, from the series "Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji (Fugaku sanjūrokkei)"
The Herring Net
shortDesc: One of the most influential American painters of the 19th century, Winslow Homer is known for his dynamic depictions of both upper-class leisure pursuits and nature's power and beauty. The paintings he created after 1882 focus almost exclusively on humankind’s contest with nature. Here, Homer depicted the heroic efforts of fishermen hauling in an abundant catch of herring while steadying their boat amid turbulent swells.

title: Madame de Pastoret and Her Son
The Holy Family with Saints Elizabeth and John the Baptist
Jacques and Berthe Lipchitz
shortDesc: Amedeo Modigliani created his finest paintings between 1914 and his premature death in 1920. Focusing on a limited range of subjects, mainly portraits and nudes, he developed a highly distinctive style of sensitively elongated forms. Sculptor Jacques Lipchitz commissioned Modigliani to paint this portrait on the occasion of his marriage to the poet Berthe Kitrosser as a way of helping his troubled friend financially.

title: A Sunday on La Grande Jatte — 1884
shortDesc: For his largest and best-known painting, Georges Seurat depicted Parisians enjoying all sorts of leisurely activities—strolling, lounging, sailing, and fishing—in the park called La Grande Jatte on the River Seine. He used an innovative technique called Pointillism that was inspired by optical and color theory, applying tiny dabs of different colored paint that viewers would see as a single, and Seurat believed, more brilliant hue.

title: The Old Guitarist
shortDesc: This famous work is from Picasso’s Blue Period (1901–04), a time the artist restricted himself to a cold, monochromatic blue palette and flattened forms to convey the themes of misery and alienation. The elongated figure also reflects his interest in the great 16th-century Spanish artist El Greco. The 22-year-old Picasso had sympathy for the downtrodden; at the time, knew what it meant to be penniless.

title: The Bedroom
shortDesc: In 1888, Van Gogh moved into his own homee in Arles, France. He dubbed it the “Studio of the South,” hoping that fellow artists would join him there to work. This is one of three versions he painted of his beloved Arles bedroom. While its vivid palette and dramatic perspective seem to burst with nervous vitality, Van Gogh intended the painting "to express utter repose."

artist:
Giorgio de Chirico
Italian, born Greece, 1888–1978
title: The Philosopher's Conquest
shortDesc: Giorgio de Chirico's The Philosopher’s Conquest seems rife with meaning yet remains resolutely enigmatic. The artist juxtaposed incongruous objects—a cannon and cannonballs, oversized artichokes, a clock, and a distant train—to produce what he called art that resembles “the restlessness of myth.” His work profoundly affected artists associated with the Surrealist movement, who also used similarly unconventional pairings to explore the realm of the subconscious.

title: La durée poignardée (Time Transfixed)
shortDesc: A major figure of the Surrealist movement, René Magritte approached painting as a philosophical and poetic art. In Time Transfixed, he transformed a stovepipe into a charging locomotive, situating the train in a fireplace vent so that it appears to be emerging from a railway tunnel. The surprising juxtaposition and incongruous scale of unrelated elements bring a sense of mystery to the everyday.

artist:
Natalia Goncharova
Born Tula (formerly Russian Empire, now Russia), 1881; died Paris, 1962
title: Spanish Dancer
Zapata
shortDesc: A leader of the Mexican mural movement, José Clemente Orozco painted this canvas during a self-imposed exile in the United States. Its subject, Emiliano Zapata, was a Mexican revolutionary who fought for liberty and land redistribution for the poor. Here, Orozco placed the revered rebel behind two armed soldiers and two grieving figures—creating not a sense of victory or adulation but of foreboding and ambiguity.

artist:
Claude Gellée, called Claude Lorrain
French, 1600-1682
title: View of Delphi with a Procession
Croquet Scene
shortDesc: One of America’s foremost painters, Winslow Homer began his career as an illustrator. In the late 1860s, he turned to oil painting, depicting figures bathed in sunlight. These early paintings feature scenes of upper-class leisure pursuits—in this case, women and men playing the popular sport of croquet, a game which had recently been introduced to the United States from the British Isles.

artist:
India
Rajasthan, Mewar, Udaipur, attributed to Ghasi (active c. 1820-36)
title: Maharana Bhim Singh in Procession

artist:
Maria Helena Vieira da Silva
French, born Portugal, 1908–1992
title: Composition

artist: Peter Blume (American, born Smorgon, Russian Empire, now Belarus, 1906–1992)
title: The Rock
shortDesc: Peter Blume often spent years on a single painting; this work took four years to complete. As is often the case with Blume's work, the complex imagery—a shattered red rock resting on top of a base that is being demolished by the workers below—resists easy interpretation. It may point to devastation and reconstruction, reflecting the turbulence of World War II and its aftermath.

title: Legends of the Yūzū Nembutsu Sect
shortDesc: Commissioned and executed in the mid-14th century, this lengthy horizontal scroll illustrates the founding of the Yūzū Nembutsu sect of Japanese Buddhism. Yūzū Nembutsu means “chanting [Amida’s] name in communion”—a reference to the belief that one person chanting the Amida Buddha’s name would affect all other beings, whether in attaining individual rebirth or allowing souls in hell to be saved.

title: The Fountains
shortDesc: In his paintings of ruins, Hubert Robert embodied French philosopher Denis Diderot's notion that "Everything vanishes, everything dies, only time endures." This work, one of four canvases commissioned for a wealthy financier’s château (all now in the Art Institute's collection), exploits Robert’s typical vocabulary of fictive niches, arches, coffered vaults, colonnades, majestic stairwells, and Roman statuary to create a fantasy of expansive space.

artist:
Marc Chagall
Born Vitebsk (formerly Russian Empire, now Belarus), 1887; died Saint-Paul, France, 1985
title: White Crucifixion
shortDesc: This work is one of the most overtly political paintings of Chagall's career. It is the first in a series of works in which the artist portrayed Christ as a Jewish martyr and connected the Nazis with Christ’s tormentors, calling attention to the persecution and suffering of Jewish people in 1930s Germany.

title: Cupid Chastised
shortDesc: This dramatic scene by Bartolomeo Manfredi shows Mars, the god of war, beating Cupid for having caused his affair with Venus, the goddess of love. The sheer physicality of the figures as well as the bold illumination from the left further the work's dynamism. The composition is on one level a tale of domestic disturbance but also symbolizes the eternal conflict between love and war.

title: Landscape with the Ruins of the Castle of Egmond
Merahi metua no Tehamana (Tehamana Has Many Parents or The Ancestors of Tehamana)
At the Moulin Rouge
shortDesc: Toulouse-Lautrec made a career depicting colorful personalities from Parisian cabarets and dance halls like the Moulin Rouge. He populated this painting with that nightclub's regulars, including himself—the diminutive figure in the center background. Dancer La Goulue arranges her hair behind the table where Jane Avril, another performer, socializes. Singer May Milton peers out from the painting's right edge, her face harshly lit and acid green.

title: Still Life with Dead Game, Fruits, and Vegetables in a Market
Madame Cezanne in a Yellow Chair
Silver Sun
shortDesc: In 1910 and 1911, Arthur Dove became the first American painter to experiment with pure abstraction, and by the 1920s he was developing a unique representational style that simplified elements and toyed with scale to capture the fundamental forms and forces of nature. Here, shimmering concentric circles of silver and blue radiate downward from a black sun, dwarfing its reflection in the water below.

title: The Fountain, Villa Torlonia, Frascati, Italy
shortDesc: The year 1907 was a turning point for John Singer Sargent; the sought-after portraitist stepped away from his successful portraiture career to pursue plein-air landscape painting. This work, depicting his traveling companions and fellow artists Wilfrid and Jane Emmet de Glehn, captures that moment of transition. Combining landscape and portraiture, the composition speaks to friendship and painterly pursuits while also celebrating color, light, and movement.

title: Untitled
dimension: Two sets of four joined panels, each panel: 200.1 × 59.7 cm (78 3/4 × 23 1/2 in.)

artist:
Lyonel Feininger
American, worked in Germany, 1871–1956
title: Carnival in Arcueil

artist:
Willem de Kooning
American, born Netherlands, 1904–1997
title: Excavation
shortDesc: When completed in 1950, William de Kooning's Excavation was his largest painting. The composition straddles representation and abstraction with its structure of hooked, calligraphic lines that define bird and fish shapes, human noses, eyes, teeth, necks, and jaws. The apt title reflects his painting process: an intensive building up of the surface and scraping down of its paint layers until the desired effect was achieved.

artist:
India
Designed by Basawan, painted by Shankar
title: The Young Emperor Akbar Arrests the Insolent Shah Abu’l-Maali, page from a manuscript of the Akbarnama
Bathers by a River
shortDesc: Matisse worked on this painting for years, increasingly restricting the palette and abstracting the forms. His faceless figures are composed of simplified shapes; one steps into a thick, black band that seems to represent the river, while a white, snakelike form slithers near another bather’s feet. The artist considered this painting one of his most pivotal in the evolution of his mature style.

title: Self-Portrait
shortDesc: Van Gogh’s face is as well known as his art—in fact, it is inseparable from it. The artist painted more than 35 self-portraits over his lifetime. This one was created in Paris under the influence of Seurat and pointillism. The intense dabs of paint and color, anchored by his eyes, create a turbulent energy, giving the viewer a deep sense of the artist’s presence.

title: Acrobats at the Cirque Fernando (Francisca and Angelina Wartenberg)
shortDesc: The two girls in this painting by Pierre-Auguste Renoir are Francisca and Angelina Wartenberg, acrobats who performed in the famed Cirque Fernando in Paris. They are depicted clutching oranges tossed to them from the crowd as gifts. Although they are painted standing in the center of a circus ring, Renoir actually painted them in his studio, where he could take full advantage of natural sunlight.

title: That Which I Should Have Done I Did Not Do (The Door)
Self-Portrait
shortDesc: Among the boldest and the most brilliantly colored of Max Beckmann’s self-portraits, this work was perhaps the last painting the artist completed in Berlin before he and his wife fled to the Netherlands—just two days after Adolf Hitler delivered a speech condemning modern art. In 1937, shortly after this work was made, more than 500 of his works were confiscated from German public collections.

artist:
El Greco (Doménikos Theotokópoulos)
Greek, active in Spain, 1541–1614
title: The Assumption of the Virgin
shortDesc: This painting was the central element of an altarpiece that was El Greco’s ﬁrst major Spanish commission and large public work. The Virgin ﬂoats upward on the crescent moon, a symbol of her purity, while the apostles express amazement and concern. El Greco’s broad brushstrokes and bold color made this painting a favorite of modern artists such as Pablo Picasso and Mary Cassatt.

title: The Two Disciples at the Tomb
Retable and Frontal of the Life of Christ and the Virgin Made for Pedro López de Ayala

artist:
Suzuki Harunobu 鈴木 春信 
Japanese, 1725 (?)-1770
title: Evening Snow on a Floss Shaper (Nurioke no bosetsu), from the series "Eight Views of the Parlor (Zashiki hakkei)"

artist:
Toshusai Sharaku 東洲斎 写楽
Japanese, active 1794-95
title: The actor Bando Mitsugoro II as Ishii Genzo
Distant View of Niagara Falls
shortDesc: By the 19th century, Niagara Falls was already an iconic American landscape, nearly verging on mythical. Thomas Cole visited the landmark in May 1829 and composed this romanticized, autumnal scene the following year. In amplifying the natural grandeur of the American landscape, the artist wilfully ommitted the factories, scenic overlooks, and hotels that populated the area in the early 19th century.

title: Into the World There Came a Soul Called Ida
Portrait of a Man in Costume
Old Man with a Gold Chain
shortDesc: In his character studies, Rembrandt explored the effect of a single figure, made dramatic through the use of rich, subtle lighting and costumes, which the artist collected to transform his models. Here, the gold chain and steel gorget suggest an honored military career, while the plumed beret evokes an earlier time. The unidentified sitter, once thought to be the artist’s father, was a favorite model.

title: The Advance-Guard, or The Military Sacrifice (The Ambush)

artist:
Mark Rothko (Marcus Rothkowitz)
American, born Russia (Latvia), 1903–1970
title: Untitled (Purple, White, and Red)
Magnolias on Light Blue Velvet Cloth
Sky above Clouds IV
shortDesc: Painted in the summer of 1965, when Georgia O’Keeffe was 77 years old, this monumental work is the final painting in a series the artist made based on her experiences as an airplane passenger. Because of its size and its status as an icon of the museum's collection, the work has not left the Art Institute since it came into the building in 1983.

title: The Shelton with Sunspots, N.Y.
shortDesc: In 1925, Georgia O'Keeffe moved to the 30th floor of the New York's Shelton Hotel, then the tallest hotel in the world. Fascinated by the building's height, she painted a series of celebratory cityscapes. She described this scene as an "optical illusion of a bite out of one side of the tower made by the sun, with sunspots against the building and against the sky."

title: The Battle between the Gods and the Giants
Train Station
shortDesc: Born in Georgia, Walter Ellison moved to Chicago in the 1920s, one of more than six million African Americans who left the South for the promise of a better life. After studying at the School of the Art Institute, the artist began exhibiting his paintings depicting scenes of Black Americans during the Great Migration, like this one of a segregated train station.

title: TAKEN FROM HERE TO WHERE IT CAME FROM AND TAKEN TO A PLACE AND USED IN SUCH A MANNER THAT IT CAN ONLY REMAIN AS A REPRESENTATION OF WHAT IT WAS WHERE IT CAME FROM

artist:
Marc Chagall
Born Vitebsk (formerly Russian Empire, now Belarus), 1887; died Saint-Paul, France, 1985
title: America Windows
shortDesc: At the end of World War II, Marc Chagall sought new avenues for artistic experimentation and turned to the medium of stained glass, which allowed him to explore intense color on a monumental scale. This six-panel work, a gift from the artist, merges symbols of American history, the Chicago skyline, and the arts: music, painting, literature, architecture, theater, and dance.

title: Love of Winter
shortDesc: “There has been none of my favorite snow," George Bellows wrote to a friend in January 1914. "I must always paint the snow at least once a year.” Soon after, a blizzard hit New York City, inspiring this painting. The bright colors and broad brushstrokes convey the pleasuire and movement of the skaters and onlookers who are out enjoying a New York City winter.

title: Lozenge Composition with Yellow, Black, Blue, Red, and Gray
shortDesc: Piet Mondrian, a founding member of the international movement De Stijl (the Style), said “the straight line tells the truth.” Deceptively simple, his works are the result of continual tinkering to achieve absolute balance and harmony. In this work, Mondrian rotated a square canvas 90 degrees to create a dynamic relationship between the rectilinear composition and the diagonal lines of the painting's edges.

title: The Combat of the Giaour and Hassan

artist:
Master of the Housebook
German, active c. 1470-1500
title: The Road to Calvary
dimension: Image: 12.9 × 19.3 cm (5 1/8 × 7 5/8 in.); Sheet, trimmed within platemark: 13 × 19.4 cm (5 1/8 × 7 11/16 in.)

artist:
William Michael Harnett
American, born Ireland, 1848–1892
title: For Sunday's Dinner
The Child's Bath
shortDesc: Known for her sensitive yet unsentimental scenes of women and children, Mary Cassatt was the only American invited to exhibit with the original French Impressionist group. In The Child’s Bath, one of her masterworks, she used cropped forms, bold patterns and outlines, and a flattened perspective, all of which she derived from her study of Japanese woodblock prints.<

artist:
Francisco José de Goya y Lucientes
Spanish, 1746–1828
title: Boy on a Ram
The Garden of Palazzo Contarini dal Zaffo
shortDesc: This painting by Francesco Guardi, an 18th-century landscape painter renowned for his inventive city views, depicts a luxurious Venetian green space. Elegant couples stroll, while a ballgame takes place in the distance and a single gondola slides across the lagoon. Guardi's city scenes were particularly popular with wealthy travelers making the grand tour of Europe as evidence of their extravagant trips.

title: Cabin in the Cotton
shortDesc: A celebrated African American artist of the mid-20th century, self-taught painter Horace Pippin began painting as therapy, hoping to regain mobility in his right arm, which was injured during WWI. While this work hung in a Philadelphia shoe repair shop, it caught the attention of artists, critics, and gallerists. It is considered an exemplar of the artist's vivid, saturated palette and feeling for intense pattern.

title: Nighthawks
shortDesc: One of the best-known images of 20th-century art, Edward Hopper's Nighthawks depicts an all-night diner where three customers, all lost in their own thoughts, have congregated. It’s unclear how or why the anonymous and uncommunicative night owls are there. While Hopper mostly avoided commenting on his intent for the work, he did share, “unconsciously, probably, I was painting the loneliness of a large city.”

title: The Policeman
shortDesc: After moving to Paris in 1920, Joan Miró met a group of avant-garde artists who advocated merging the everyday world with dreams and the unconscious to produce an absolute reality, or surreality. In The Policeman, Miró derives an image of a mustachioed policeman and his horse from seemingly unplanned stains on the canvas and graffiti-like strokes and squiggles, as if composing without conscious intention.

title: The Earth Is a Man
shortDesc: Matta referred to this imaginative landscape—his best-known painting—as an “inscape.” He painted it in honor of the poet Federico García Lorca, who was assassinated in 1936, and used the technique of psychic automatism, developed by the Surrealists, to create the composition's turbulent forms. Exhibited in New York City, the mural-size canvas influenced a new generation of American artists: the Abstract Expressionists.

title: Nightlife
shortDesc: A native Chicagoan and graduate of the School of the Art Institute, Archibald Motley used his art to represent the vibrancy of African American culture, frequently portraying young, sophisticated city dwellers out on the town. One of Motley’s most celebrated paintings, Nightlife depicts a crowded cabaret in the South Side Bronzeville neighborhood. The dynamic composition, intense lighting, and heightened colors vividly express the scene's liveliness.

title: The Wedding
shortDesc: Known for his depictions of Black American life, Jacob Lawrence composed this vibrant marriage scene. Positioning the bride and groom with their backs to us, Lawrence invites us as guests to the couple’s special day. The brightly colored flowers and boldly patterned stained glass give the scene movement and energy, adding to the joyful spirit of the painting.

title: Starry Night and the Astronauts
shortDesc: Alma Thomas was enthralled by astronauts and outer space. This painting, made when she was 81, showcases that fascination through her signature style of short, rhythmic strokes of paint. “Color is life, and light is the mother of color,” she once proclaimed. In 1972, she became the first African American woman to have a solo exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York.

artist:
Pablo Picasso (Spanish, 1881-1973)
printed by Roger Lacourière (French, 1892-1966)
title: Weeping Woman I
The Interior of the Palm House on the Pfaueninsel Near Potsdam
Two Cows and a Young Bull beside a Fence in a Meadow
Woman Descending the Staircase (Frau die Treppe herabgehend)
Elizabeth Grant Bankson Beatty (Mrs. James Beatty) and Her Daughter Susan
shortDesc: Joshua Johnson, one of the first prominent African American artists, was known for his portraits of white middle-class families. The son of a white man and an enslaved woman, Johnson was originally enslaved before becoming free when he came of age. His story of extraordinary success and talent in the face of injustice is one that must be remembered in the history of American art.

title: The Girl by the Window
shortDesc: Edvard Munch’s life and art have come to epitomize modern notions of anxiety. Created the same year as his renowned The Scream, this painting depicts a young girl in her nightgown gazing out at the city from her darkened room. The steep angle of the floor and the deep shadows that obliterate almost everything in the room create an unsettling and enigmatic scene.

title: Red Yellow Blue White and Black II

artist:
Edvard Munch (Norwegian, 1863-1944)
printed by Auguste Clot (French, 1858-1936)
title: The Sick Child I
Group Pilgrimage to the Jizo Nun
Forest and Sun
shortDesc: Surrealist Max Ernst used an unusually wide range of styles and techniques to create his works. In 1925, he developed a method called frottage, which involved rubbing paper or canvas over a textured surface to create an image. In Forest and Sun, the wood grain patterns become a cluster of towering forms recalling a forest, a source of fear and fascination for Ernst since his youth.

title: The First Part of the Return from Parnassus
Wall Drawing #821: A black square divided horizontally and vertically into four equal parts, each with a different direction of alternating flat and glossy bands
The Room No. VI
shortDesc: Eldzier Cortor lived in Chicago and attended the School of the Art Institute. While drawn to abstraction, he felt that it was not an effective tool for conveying serious social and political concerns. In this painting, the artist exposed the impoverished living conditions of many African Americans on Chicago's South Side through a brilliant use of line and color, reinvigorating the idiom of social realism.

title: The Captive Slave (Ira Aldridge)
shortDesc: This painting by John Philip Simpson is both a powerful abolitionist statement and a striking portrait of the celebrated Shakespearean actor Ira Aldridge. A freeborn American, Aldridge became the first Black man to play Othello on the London stage in 1833. Simpson’s painting highlights Aldridge’s gifts of expression as a tragic actor.

artist:
Kazimir Malevich
Born Kyiv (formerly Russian Empire, now Ukraine), 1878; died Saint Petersburg, 1935
title: Painterly Realism of a Football Player—Color Masses in the 4th Dimension

artist:
India
Rajasthan, Mewar, Udaipur, attributed to the “Stipple Master” (active c. 1692-c. 1715)
title: A Monumental Portrait of a Monkey
dimension: Outermost border: 48.5 × 58.7 cm (19 × 23 in.); Image: 45 × 56 cm (17 3/4 × 22 in.)

title: Golden Wings Brushing the Clouds Incarnated from Earthly Wide Star (Chikatsusei Maunkinshi)
Target
shortDesc: Throughout his career, pioneering artist Jasper Johns repeatedly explored various symbols, including numbers, the American flag, and the alphabet. The target was among the earliest of these recurring motifs: from 1955 to 1961 he produced several dozen paintings and drawings, including this work, that used the symbol as a means of exploring the color and character of his mark making in various mediums.

title: Liz #3 [Early Colored Liz]
shortDesc: No artist is more closely associated with advertising, consumer culture, and mass media than Andy Warhol. Through his brazen appropriation of images—from soup cans to movie stars—and his radical use of the silkscreen process, Warhol became synonymous with Pop Art. This painting is from a series of 13 works, each featuring the same image of Elizabeth Taylor (cropped from a publicity still) on a jewel-toned background.

title: Finnish Painting
shortDesc: Pope.L is known for groundbreaking performances as well as text-based drawings and paintings that disrupt the conventions of cultural identity and explode traditional artistic categories. This work presents the barely legible text of a poem, the last word of which is “decode”—as if acknowledging that to see, read, and understand others is always a struggle, and that meaning is often fluid.

title: Small Town by Day (Badische Kleinstadt bei Tage)
